doc.title: Singtel
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Come out positive from Singtel investor day firing on all cylindersCome out positive from Singtel investor day firing on_2025-08-29

passages.text: Maintain Rating: BUY | PO: 5.00 SGD | Price: 4.31 SGD

Singtel held their investor day today with meetings with Singtel mgmt. and the mgmt. of their core businesses + associate cos. Mgmt. highlighted they are comfortable to pay VRD for another 5 years, until FY30 (even at high end of 6 cents), longer than consensus' 3 yrs. until FY28 - creating dividend upside. Further, mgmt. indicated they're well on track to deliver the S\$9bn capital recycling, driven by gradual Bharti stake sale along with other assets - including stake in other opcos, infra-assets and real estate assets. Mgmt. indicated this is a conservative target and there could be upside to it.

Optus mgmt. is working towards ROIC uplift to high single digits - this is being driven by ARPU growth, margin improvement and capex intensity decline. On margins, Optus mgmt. sees significant upside with Oz telco peers at \(32 - 36\%\) EBITDA margin, vs their \(27\%\) . On the SG biz - mgmt. is more confident of growth with the consolidation in SG market and growth in Enterprise business ( \(50\%\) of SG biz revenue).

We were encouraged by Mgmt.'s target of \(30 - 35\%\) EBITDA contribution from the growth engines, i.e. NCS and Nxera in the medium term. While we believe the target is ambitious, we see a path to achieving this with margin growth at NCS and delivery of new DCs in SG and TH. We see upside to our and consensus NCS numbers with Al related project revenue growth. On DC business - the capacity delivery target is now increased to \(>400MW\) in the medium term along with a new DC project in Japan.

We came out positive from the investor day, with mgmt. confident of delivering on ROIC growth, margin uplift, and capital recycling. We believe key incremental catalysts would be i) Share buyback execution: Mgmt. has set a 3- yr target for their S\$2bn share buyback (from May'25) and will execute basis certain objective measures ii) Guidance raise: mgmt. indicated they're not increasing the guidance for now but will revisit with 1H25 results. We maintain Buy with a PO of S\$5.0 as we believe Singtel is set to deliver.
\\* For full definitions of Qmethod means, see page 11.

Key Metrics\\* For full definitions of iQmethod measures, see page 11.
Telecom Services-Wireless/Cellular

Singtel is the incumbent telecommunications provider in Singapore, competing across all segments of the market. It also owns \(100\%\) of Australian operator, Optus, which competes in fixed and mobile markets. Its main investments in Asia are mobile operators including Telkomsel in Indonesia, Airtel in India, AIS/GULF Development in Thailand and Globe in the Philippines.

We have a Buy rating on the stock due to its diverse asset mix and exposure to some of the leading EM telcos in South Asia. Its dominant positions in SG and Australia also help it generate high cash flows and support its dividend yield.
ST28: Mgmt. said that since the announcement of ST28 May24 they're happy to have been executing. Last year they reported \(20\%\) EBIT growth and another \(11\%\) in 1Q26.
Cost out program: mgmt. was also happy to be in the third year of their 3 yr. \(\) 600m\(cm cost out program - delivering\) \ \(200m\) in cost savings annually across Optus and Singtel Singapore.

Capital recycling: On the \(\) 59bn\(capital recycling program that Singtel has set for the medium term, mgmt. reiterated that they've achieved\) \ \(54bn\) so far, with another \(\) 55bn\(to come - which includes a\) \ \(2bn\) share buyback program announced until FY28.

Optus ROIC growth: Optus' focus on ROIC growth is very clear - mgmt. said it wouldn't be overnight, but they'd consistently move to high single digit ROIC and focus on value, service, and quality. Building network resilience is also a big area of focus for Optus.

Data centers: Mgmt. said that the DCs are scaling very nicely - the currently capacity will double very soon, and therefore the EBITDA will also double. The new DCs will all be AI ready. Of the \(>400MW\) AI DC pipeline, 200MW will be delivered by Dec'26. A lot of the DC capacity they'll be delivering are already pre- sold.

Singtel Singapore: Singtel Singapore has launched a \(5G+\) network - which carves out a slice of the 5G network for the premium segment - mgmt. expects this to differentiate Singtel from competition and is seeing good early signs. They're also seeing good momentum on the enterprise business growth.

Artificial Intelligence: mgmt. shared that at the group level they're embracing AI at scale. It's not just about reducing costs and improving productivity, but also about delivering differentiated experience and looking at targeted revenue growth and customization of offers.

Outlook: Mgmt. said they're keeping their outlook unchanged now because it's still very early in the financial year, but they'll continue to assess progress and do a refresh in the mid term with 1H25 results.
Capital partnerships and inorganic growth - Mgmt. also called out that they do believe in capital partnerships and leveraging on private capital for certain asset classes.

Value realization dividends - Mgmt. said they're comfortable to deliver value realization dividend for another 5 years until FY30 - they need \(\) 50bn-\ \(51bn\) in dividends at the book ends, and beyond that management expects the core dividend to grow enough to catch- up and allow total dividend to sustain.

Optus mgmt. shared they cover \(98.5\%\) of the population in Australia with both 5G and 4G. They have 7700 towers - of which \(4000+\) have been upgraded to 5G and the rest will be upgraded over next few years.

The telco industry in Australia has \(6 - 8\%\) ROIC - its lower because of the size of the country and the need to build infrastructure across the continent. The challenge for Optus - why they have an even lower ROIC is because they've had lower margins vs. competition. ROIC repair will be a focus for management.

Strategy - i) to rebuild trust and reputation ii) to refocus on core connectivity - this was the leading driver behind offloading Optus Sports recently and iii) to modernize infrastructure and simplify operations.

Competition continues to be intense in Tier 2 - the pricing of Tier 2 operators is much lower than the tier 1 players, but within tier 1 - Optus us below Telstra - and the pricing gap has widened - so the hope there is an opportunity to narrow this over time, but it may be a while until the next hike.

Capex - Mgmt. forecasts A \(1.4bn in capex in FY26 - with 50\%\) of it going into building network resilience. Mgmt. expects capex to sales ration to come down. It has come down to \(18\%\) of revenue - but peak now behind so should come down to \(15\%\) with the lower capital intensity, however there can be some lumpy satellite capex.
Enterprise - Mgmt. believes they're weak in the- mid market segment and that creates an opportunity for them.
TPG network sharing deal - The MOCN partnership with TPG only went live at the start of this year, so we'll start seeing benefits of this in the years to come.
MVNO pricing improving - Even among the MVNOs we have seen price increases recently - at both ALDI mobile and Amaysim.
Digital InfraCo tech stack - Mgmt. believes Singtel is uniquely positioned with its Ai tech stack to serve the growing AI generation needs in Singapore and some of its key markets.
Nxera - currently Singtel has 60MW of DC capacity live in Singapore under Nxera, but this is soon expanding to \(>200MW\) delivered capacity by Dec'26and further \(>400MW\) in the medium term.

GPUaaS - Mgmt. explained that in the last one year they were testing out the feasibility of this offering, and while they're not ready to take on inventory risk until a customer has committed to a 3- 5- year contract, they're now seeing enough demand for this business and have unlocked the feasibility of this business. This now sits in their RE.AI layer.

Japan DC: Nxera will be adding their latest Data Center in Japan. This is \(51\% - 49\%\) JV with Hitachi. They've partnered with Hitachi as it is the largest MEP player in Japan and will help shorten their time to entry in the market and bring local customers + expertise. This DC could be expected to be delivered in FY28 - FY29

DC Tuas: The DC Tuas in Singapore is scheduled for launch in Jan'2026. Per mgmt., by the time of launch, this will be the largest liquid cooled infrastructure in this part of the world. Tuas also has an advantage as it's a cable landing station - with 5 subsea cables landing into it.

Revenue breakdown - Singtel Singapore had about \(\) 3.8bn\(in revenues last year - of which 50\%\) came from consumer and 50% enterprise. Within enterprise - about \(30\%\) (15% of total revenue) comes from International - which includes some of the use cases like connected cars and enterprise solutions like the one they created for Nestle.

Growth: In FY25 Singtel Singapore was able to turn its EBITDA decline trend - and show \(2\%\) yoy EBITDA growth because of the cost out initiatives. On the revenue side - consumer business had declined \(4\%\) yoy due to hypercompetition and
enterprise was stable. With the consolidation in SG market the consumer growth is expected to be better.

Issues with M1- Simba consolidation: One of the issues M1 and Simba will have to resolve is that SIMBA and M1 are on different network and have unequal lots - as M1 had returned one lot. Also M1 shares its 5G network with Starhub.

AI centralization: Singtel Singapore has decided to centralize AI deployment under the CEO instead of the CTO. The thought process was to move away from AI blooming everywhere and instead have a well though process while looking at their data architecture.

5G investments: Singtel sees \(20\%\) of their customers contribute to \(60\%\) of their revenue. Therefore they see good value in being able to hold on to the higher ARPU customers - however the 5G slicing is not very cost intensive and their past their peak 5G capex.
Capex - lowering capex/sales ratio to low teens per mgmt. as peak capex in 5G is behind.
- 700MHz spectrum - The spectrum was originally for 4G- but Singtel decided to use it for 5G. This allowed them to overnight improve their 5G coverage quality by \(40\%\)

- Customer experience - management said they intend to compete on customer service and not on pricing. They've also been doing network slicing to create a better network experience for their high-end customers.
- Legacy - legacy revenues now contribute about \(9\%\) of TSEL's total revenue now, and it is declining at c. \(30\%\) yoy. It is expected to go down to a stable state of \(4 - 5\%\) in 1-1.5 yrs.

- Data traffic - has grown nicely at double digit yoy, however mgmt. alluded to the fact that payload growth has not been well monetized. Mgmt. said they wanted to give users a reason to use their network. For customer base attached to a digital service is seen to have much higher stickiness.
- Fixed broadband- this business has 10mn customers - a \(10\%\) yoy growth, when Indihome was transferred to Telkomsel two years ago - the convergence was at \(37\%\) , now it is at \(55\%\) .
- 5G advancement - have been advancing in a careful and deliberate manner. Now in 5G cities.
- AI deployment - have been leveraging AI to improve external customer experience and improving internal operations, proactive regarding network deployment. Also adopted AI enabled CVM.

- Digital channel - Mgmt. shared that their super app My Telkomsel now has 60mn MAUs and it is beyond just connectivity transactions - so they want to strengthen the platform, with other actions of growth.

- Broadband: Mgmt. said that Broadband is a demand led business and as they were rolling out - they saw a fair bit of competition in the low ends segment. The two things they're doing in broadband are - i) eliminating some of their low speed packs like 10Mbps, and move customers to 20Mbps and now 30Mbps and ii) doing land grab - expanding their home passes in ex Java

Bharti has also removed the entry level data plan after its competitor did. Mgmt considers this a step in the right direction. ARPU growth will come from natural cycle of upgradation. On 5G, monetization will pick- up when the unlimited 5G plans will be removed.

On tariff hikes, mgmt. believes if the industry structure improves then it's a great scenario for everyone. If not, then we could see a few more rounds of tariff hikes taking ARPU from c. Rs 250 to Rs 350. From there, uptake could be more measured. The incremental margins on tariff hike are very healthy for Bharti;

Bharti mgmt would like India telcos to remain a three- operator market. Any potential extension in AGR payments would help get the sector & Bharti some relief and by extension we also get some relief;

Over the next few years, Bharti's FCF will likely improve. Deleveraging is the first focus for mgmt, paying dividends is the second one and the third is identifying growth areas (like cloud, data centers, lending) and investing there;

Bharti's subsidiary Indus will continue to explore share buybacks, dividend options. Indus not paying dividend this time was a one- off. Bharti Africa generates FCF and is a dividend paying asset. Bharti will continue to climb up its stake. Currency volatility in Africa is a challenge.

In the broadband market, two operators (Bharti and Jio) are consolidating the market. Bharti is now neck to neck in share of acquisitions. The priority is to provide fiber broadband to the household. If fiber is not available, then Bharti will offer fixed wireless. The cost per connected home pass is the same for fiber and fixed wireless, but fiber is always better. 5G slicing provides a large opportunity (currently its scale is small). Bharti's experiments with UBR have not been promising.

On datacenters, Bharti will double down investments in data centers - c. 130- 140MW capacity for its customers and another 80 MW for self- use. Bharti is in discussions with global hyperscalers for AI (not so much with domestic enterprises). Mgmt. wants to build the business right now, not focusing on any stake sale.

Bharti has its own cloud. Bharti has workflow platforms (buy- bill- pay- serve) and channel platforms. Bharti is taking the same platforms and creating AI on top of it. This is leading to better adjacencies, lowering costs and improving capital efficiency.

The digital platforms are running at scale. Of the 16 opcos in Africa, 7 are using it. Bharti is using open- source platforms to create these networks. However, they need to guard against security issues, manage hallucinations (through training its own Small language models).
Bharti is done a tremendous amount of work on fraud reduction. The company has seen \(80\%\) reduction in the fraud on its network and wants to reduce this further and become a no fraud network.

NCS operates in 3 regions - Singapore and Southeast Asia, Australia and Greater China and they have presence in 20 cities, and they have 13,000 employees. They look at traditional and next generation IT services and they look at three segments - enterprise, government, and telcos.
- New business – mgmt. said they're seeing strong growth in their new businesses segment, with cloud and AI related businesses now contributing to 57% of their revenue.

- AI – Mgmt. said that AI has been featuring in a big way in services they provide to their clients. They see themselves in a unique position of leverage AI – as they can deploy it externally for the users, but also internally to drive efficiency.
- Industry diversification – Given their origin NCS is very strong in the government sector, in the other new businesses they see themselves as the challenger.
- Growth framework – mgmt. said that they bring value to clients by taking the best of technology to clients. They can partner with their partners like AWS, Google etc. to their clients.

- Margin across the 3 segments – Mgmt. indicated that typically there are lower margins in certain industries and services – is often lower because they're investing there in a big way. In the investment phase – they see lower margins.

- Margin outlook – mgmt. indicated that they're looking at programmatic margin improvement. Until last year they were in Horizon 1 – which was their investment phase – but they're now in Horizon 2 and are seeing benefits of those investments.

- Mobile business – The market is pretty much at a 50-50% balance – and this dynamic is expected to continue. Mgmt. believes they have a superior network, have been improving customer service and in addition have value added services, while the competitor is in the final stages of blending in two companies and adjusting their network. They've gained wallet share on 5G and value-added services.

- Network quality – Mgmt. believes their superiors network is driven by – i) the proper spectrum planning, ii) the location and the number of towers and sites and iii) how they operate and maintain the reliabilities – continue to reduce downtime.

- Subscriber share – the market net adds have been small, last year the net adds went negative since the govt. introduced personal identification for SIM cards, especially for prepaid. The gain in subscribers has mostly been organic.

- EPL strategy – The strategy is to provide customers the experience to access entertainment content – they've been outing themselves as an aggregator – this includes all OTT and linear channels, and now they're adding EPL through a collaboration with JAS (who own the rights for EPL).

- Broadband – The penetration in Thailand is about 50% of the occupied households – the market is still growing but will continue to grow at a slower pace of maybe 5% annually. AIS still captures majority of the new net adds in the market – partly because they combined the business with 3BB, so they have a lot more resources footprint. NT is the one losing in the market.

- Data Center – The market in Thailand has been growing – for the AIS-Gulf-Singtel DC entity – the first phase of 35MW is ready, another 30MW will be added in phase 2 and 30MW in phase 3. There is a second DC also scheduled to open. A lot of demand from government, local enterprise, and global hyperscalers.

- KPA: Mgmt. said they're very open to universal access in the Philippines, but there are some security concerns with the law currently, which are i) no vetting is required ii) no proper cybersecurity iii) potential spectrum sharing and iv) level playing field

- G-Cash 
- The G-Cash contribution to Globe earnings continue to improve 
- and was at 26% for 2Q. Mgmt. is not able to divulge the contribution of gaming to Globe but is confidant on growth of this business. From the telco side the main synergy is as a recharge channel 
- as it can seed more users into the app, and because digital channels are also cheaper than the traditional channels.

- Customer experience 
- Globe is focusing on customer experience through site expansion and site builds, and through improving their retail base. Opening of stores is critical for the postpaid customer base 
- and was a driver of growth in the second quarter.

- Prepaid Fiber 
- One third of Globe's wired subscribers are now prepaid fiber subscribers 
- and they're seeing very good reload rates from these subscribers.

- Fiber ports 
- Globe has 4mn ports and 1.5mn users, so they still have some room to grow. But the competition is estimated to have 8-9mn ports. Globe is willing to lease ports from other providers if they're willing, as long as they're in areas where they believe there could be a strategic advantage.

VRD: Value Realization Dividend  MVNO: Mobile virtual network operator  ROIC: Return on invested capital  AIS: Advanced Info Services  SG: Singapore  NCS: NCS Singapore (previously National Computer systems)  CVM: Customer value maximization  BTS: Base Transceiver station  ARPU: Average revenue per user  AI: Artificial intelligence  DC: Data center  FWA: Fixed wireless access  BB: Broadband  GPUaaS: Graphic processing unit as a service  MW: Mega watts  UBR: Unlicensed band radio  KPA: Konektadong Pinoy Act  OTT: over-the-top media  JAS: Jasmine International Public Company Limited  EPL: English Premier League  TSEL: Telkomsel  MOCN: Multiple Operator Core Network  TPG: TPG Telecom Limited  TH: Thailand  MEP: Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing  AGR: Adjusted Gross Revenue  AWS: Amazon Web Services

Our valuation of \(\) 55\(/share is derived using sum - of - the - parts methodology. We value the consolidated (Singapore, Digital Infra co (Nxera) and Optus) businesses using DCF valuation (Singapore: WACC of 7.5%, terminal growth: 1%, Digital Infra Co. - WACC of 7.5%, terminal growth: 3.0%, Optus: WACC of 8.3%, terminal growth: 1.0%) and crosschecking the outcome with EBITDA multiples. Our consolidated DCF valuation implies a 25x FY26E P/E. We value the Bharti Airtel participation with an SOTP, where we analyze the core business using a DCF with a WACC of 11.2% and terminal growth rate of 3.5%. For Advanced Info we use the average of our DCF (using a 9% WACC and a 1.0% terminal growth rate) and a 9.5x target EV/EBITDA historical fair value. We use a DCF - based valuation for Telkomsel (TSEL).

Downside risks: 1) aggressive mobile pricing or lower- than- expected usage of mobile data could impact mobile revenue growth for both subsidiaries and associates, 2) material rise in handset subsidies could erode margins and returns, and 3) adverse regulations (foreign ownership limits in emerging markets, roaming regulations etc.) could have material impact due to ST's multi- country footprint.

Upside risks: 1) constructive mobile pricing or higher- than- expected usage of mobile data could lead to higher mobile revenue growth for all operating companies, 2) sooner- than- expected monetization of digital life assets, and 3) step- up on dividends via either ordinary or special payouts

qMethod is the set of BofA Global Research standard measures that serve to maintain global consistency under three broad headings: Business Performance, Quality of Earnings, and validations. The key features of iMethod are: A consistently structured, detailed, and transparent methodology. Guidelines to maximize the effectiveness of the comparative valuation process, and to identify some common pitfalls. tata is our real-time global research database that is sourced directly from our equity analysts earnings models and includes forecasted as well as historical data for income statements, balance sheets, and cash flow statements for companies covered by BofA Global Research. qProfile, qMethod are service marks of Bank of America Corporation. tata is a registered service mark of Bank of America Corporation.
profitability of the Bank's sales and trading businesses relating to the class of securities or financial instruments for which such analyst is responsible.

From time to time research analysts conduct site visits of covered issuers. BofA Global Research policies prohibit research analysts from accepting payment or reimbursement for travel expenses from the issuer for such visits.
